intro: Nothofagus pumilio, commonly known as the dwarf nothofagus or the southern beech, is a species of tree native to South America. It is characterized by its small stature, typically growing to a height of only 1–3 meters. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are usually covered in a fine, silvery pubescence. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers and is wind-pollinated. Nothofagus pumilio is an important component of the temperate rainforests in regions such as Chile and Argentina.
